column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=webanno.custom.RoleAnnotation|roles
#Text=Mr.
#Text=Diallo (Senegal) (spoke in French): I would\r
#Text=like to convey my delegation's sincere congratulations\r
#Text=for the convening of this important debate on women,\r
#Text=peace and security, which represents, Madam\r
#Text=President, the crowning moment of your remarkable\r
#Text=presidency of the Council for the month of October.
#Text=I\r
#Text=would like to thank the Secretary-General for his\r
#Text=statement, as well as Mr.
#Text=Lazarous Kapambwe,\r
#Text=President of the Economic and Social Council,\r
#Text=Ms.
#Text=Michelle Bachelet, Executive Director of\r
#Text=UN-Women, and Ms.
#Text=Orzala Ashraf Nemat,\r
#Text=representative of civil society, for their important\r
#Text=contributions.
#Text=My delegation has a special interest in the topic,\r
#Text=because resolution 1325 (2000) represented an\r
#Text=enormous step forward in the protection of women and\r
#Text=highlighted the importance of their role in all aspects\r
#Text=of United Nations peacekeeping.
#Text=Nonetheless, while it\r
#Text=has remained far from being a cure-all, resolution 1325\r
#Text=(2000) has contributed, along with resolutions 1820\r
#Text=(2008), 1888 (2009) and 1889 (2009), to improving the\r
#Text=normative framework for preventing gender-based\r
#Text=violence and for protecting women against that\r
#Text=scourge.
#Text=It should, however, be pointed out that, despite\r
#Text=those praiseworthy efforts, persistent shortcomings\r
#Text=have exposed thousands of women and girls to various\r
#Text=types of barbaric abuse and atrocities.
#Text=In fact, rape\r
#Text=continues to be used as a weapon of war in certain\r
#Text=conflict areas, and the ongoing existence of sexual and\r
#Text=gender-based violence, even at the end of a conflict,\r
#Text=represents an almost permanent threat to the security\r
#Text=and health of that vulnerable group of the population.
#Text=That is why the international community must firmly\r
#Text=commit to vigorously combating impunity in order to\r
#Text=guarantee the effective prevention of all forms of\r
#Text=violence against women.
#Text=While welcoming the zero tolerance policy on\r
#Text=sexual violence of the Secretary-General, we must, in\r
#Text=addition, insist on the need to bolster the role of\r
#Text=women in conflict-prevention and resolution.
#Text=Nevertheless, the poor results in that area have\r
#Text=undoubtedly been due to the continuing low\r
#Text=participation of women in the drafting of\r
#Text=implementation strategies.
#Text=I consider it crucial,\r
#Text=therefore, to foster women's participation by reserving\r
#Text=a key role for them in conflict-prevention policies, as\r
#Text=well as policies on peacekeeping, peacebuilding and\r
#Text=social and economic recovery.
#Text=In that context, there\r
#Text=must be a special focus on women's empowerment,\r
#Text=which will require significant investment in education,\r
#Text=training and maternal health.
#Text=In View of our considerable awareness of that\r
#Text=dynamic process, my country has allocated a\r
#Text=significant part of its budget to education and health,\r
#Text=and on 14 May 2010, it adopted a law to establish full\r
#Text=parity in all partially or fully elected bodies.
#Text=In that\r
#Text=manner, Senegal intends to ensure the effective\r
#Text=participation of women in decision-making processes.
#Text=To follow up on that law, a national gender-parity\r
#Text=monitoring body was set up and will be officially\r
#Text=inaugurated on 16 November.
#Text=Senegal has already adopted its national action\r
#Text=plan to implement resolution 1325 (2000).
#Text=Furthermore, it has sought to make a positive\r
#Text=contribution to drafting the action plan of the\r
#Text=Economic Community of West African States\r
#Text=(ECOWAS) and the Dakar Declaration by focusing on\r
#Text=the four following areas: first, effective participation of\r
#Text=women in the peace process; secondly, protection of\r
#Text=women and girls; thirdly, prevention of gender-based\r
#Text=violence through preventive diplomacy and early\r
#Text=warning systems, and fourthly, reconstruction and\r
#Text=victim assistance.
#Text=It is certain that those significant national and\r
#Text=regional level initiatives are welcome.
#Text=However, they\r
#Text=will achieve the desired success only if linked with an\r
#Text=international dynamic inspired by the Security Council\r
#Text=and based on coordinated efforts on the part of\r
#Text=UN-Women and all of the other relevant bodies.
#Text=There\r
#Text=is also a need to improve women's involvement in\r
#Text=peacekeeping operations by following up on the\r
#Text=laudable efforts already carried out in that domain.
#Text=The effective prevention of sexual violence also\r
#Text=requires stringent measures to vigorously combat the\r
#Text=root causes of conflict exacerbation.
#Text=Since there is an\r
#Text=established link between what is known as low-level\r
#Text=conflicts and wide-scale violence against women, I\r
#Text=would like to launch an appeal for coordinated and\r
#Text=focused action against the illicit trade in small arms\r
#Text=and light weapons.
#Text=In that regard, my delegation\r
#Text=cherishes the hope that the diplomatic conference of\r
#Text=2012 will enable the adoption of a robust arms trade\r
#Text=treaty.
#Text=Allow me to conclude by expressing my\r
#Text=country's conviction that the efforts to be undertaken\r
#Text=by 2015 will enable the Security Council to take stock\r
#Text=at that time of the positive implementation of\r
#Text=resolution 1325 (2000).
